text: You can certainly do it mathematically. The transition rate for three species to undergo `A+B+C-->D` at rate `lambda` would be `lambda A(t) B(t) C(t)` where `A(t)`, `B(t)` and `C(t)` are the jump processes for the number of each species. It is perfectly well-defined mathematically. However, a physics-based derivation of `lambda` would calculate probabilities of one of each reactant type getting simultaneously near each other via diffusion, which would be very small compared to the probabilities of pairs getting near each other (in dilute systems). In phenomenalogical models though it gets used, and can be fit to experimental data... Also, keep in mind this is all an approximation to what is really going on (more microscopic models would have interaction potentials between molecules and not assume everything is well-mixed...).
